title: 115_hr7099
content: The "Prevent Impaired Driving Child Endangerment Act" sanctions individuals driving intoxicated or impaired with child passengers. The "Prevent Impaired Driving Child Endangerment Act" introduces sanctions for individuals driving under the influence with child passengers, including withholding funds from noncompliant states starting in fiscal year 2020. Starting in fiscal year 2022, the Secretary will withhold 5% of funds from states that do not enforce laws against driving under the influence with child passengers. States must have laws in place to charge offenders with a felony for this offense. The individual may be charged with a felony and face up to 4 years in prison for the offense. They may also be required to install and maintain an ignition interlock system on any vehicle they own or operate for at least 6 months. Additionally, their state driver's license may be suspended during the prosecution period, but they may still be allowed to drive if they install an ignition interlock system on the vehicle. The law may require the individual to undergo an assessment for alcohol abuse, substance abuse, or mental health, and if treatment is needed, the court can mandate it as part of the sentence. The law may require an individual convicted of an offense to undergo treatment as part of their sentence or for reissuance of a driver's license. If the individual is a parent or guardian of a child passenger, a report may be filed with the State register of child abuse. Enforcing laws without waivers for sanctions on individuals related to child passengers under 21 years old. Withheld funds from a State remain available for three fiscal years. Funds may be apportioned after compliance. The Secretary will apportion withheld funds to a State if it meets compliance requirements before the deadline. The apportioned funds will be available for expenditure until the end of the third fiscal year following the year of apportionment. The funds withheld under subsection (a) will lapse if not apportioned by the end of the specified period. If a State does not meet the requirements of subsection (b), the funds will also lapse. Definitions for alcohol concentration, child, and driving while intoxicated are provided in this section. The term 'intoxicated' refers to driving a motor vehicle with a blood alcohol concentration of .08 or higher. An 'ignition interlock system' is designed to prevent starting a vehicle if the user's breath alcohol concentration is too high. A 'motor vehicle' is a vehicle powered by mechanical means for use on public highways, excluding rail-operated vehicles. The term 'State driver's license' refers to a license issued by a State for operating a motor vehicle on public highways. The Administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is tasked with educating States on child endangerment penalties for driving intoxicated with a child passenger. Sanctions for individuals driving with child passengers while intoxicated or impaired.
